Ask HN: What is the Monster.com for posting consulting work?
text: There are so many sites out there (Monster, Indeed, etc) that are focused on matching employers with employees, contract work up through FTE. Are there any sites out there dedicated to trying to match up firms that have projects they want to have consulting firms bid on, with the consulting firms that can do that work? If not, seems like a market worth inventing.

Poll: Do you host and operate your own authoritative DNS server?
text:
I am curious of two things.

- How many self host their own authoritative DNS servers these days, meaning the NS records for domains you rent point to your own self hosted DNS daemons.

- Of those that host their own, do you occasionally watch the traffic hitting your servers and observe how bot traffic has evolved and what information open resolvers are sharing with you? edns0 client subnet, etc...

I am just curious what others see. I've had some of the same bots hitting me for decades and every year the information I see evolves a little bit due to how open resolvers have also evolved.

Ask HN: Simple web and native app in a unified code base?
text:
What are some preferred ways to build and deploy a simple app (like a ToDo list) in a unified codebase across the web & native app platforms?

The ideal solution will have:

1) a single backend programming language

2) a unified (but fluid) frontend across web & native

3) portable, no vendor lock-in

4) open source, no fees (outside of hosting)

Ask HN: How to secure a database if employees are potential adversaries?
text:
Many (most?) companies secure databases using some combination of password keys or limiting the db from being publicly accessible on the internet.

But if an engineer with credentials were to get phished, or were actively malicious, these methods aren't sufficient.

What's the best practice of hardening a database from internal attacks? Let's assume there are <5 people in the company who can be fully trusted.
